creditline: Gift of funds from Mona W. Brown, the Ferndale Foundation, Barbara Jabr, Al and Mary Agnes McQuinn, Mahendra and Asha Nath, and the Ethel Morrison Van Derlip Fund
description: small writing desk having a circular floral pattern adorning the major surfaces (top, sides and front of door) with handles on either sides, hinges, top guard rail and front heart shaped lock plate of silver; ebony stand for cabinet said to be made in Portugese colony of Goa, India
medium: Desk: Rosewood, ivory inlaid with lac and silver; Stand: Ebony and other wood
text:
This deskâ€™s Indian makers used British pattern books as a guide. These forms suited their elite British market, including colonial officials. 
It incorporates local materials that were plentiful to Indian craftsmen in the 18th-century, but today they are scarce. The ebony for the stand, once abundant in southern India, is now endangered, while the rosewood of the desk is now threatened. Elephant ivory, now endangered, was in widespread use for architectural woodwork decoration in southern India.
title: Writing desk on stand
